awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Thermal Management on Multiple Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objectives of this REU site at Washington University in St. Louis are to expand student participation in thermal management research on multiple scales and to attract a diverse pool of curious, motivated students into engineering careers. A large and diverse STEM workforce is critical to global competitiveness. This REU site will help increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities in engineering careers through two proven strategies: (1) providing undergraduate research experience and (2) teaching students the societal importance of engineering through exposure to a variety of industrial, entrepreneurial, and academic career options; tours; and discussions with engineers. Students will study research topics involving heat and power, ranging from novel battery technologies, to enhanced cooling of micro-electronics and power electronics, to radiation in carbon capture processes. This will expose students to a range of engineering challenges, research methodologies, and careers that address the ever-expanding need for thermal-fluids engineers. The site will prepare students for their careers by teaching them how to communicate through oral presentations, posters, and written papers or reports. To further broaden participation, students will undertake an outreach project by assisting in teaching a short engineering course to underserved high school students in Washington University's College Prep program. 

The ability to control temperature and the transfer of thermal energy (thermal management) is critical to addressing the most important global challenges: clean and renewable energy production; inexpensive, efficient and reliable transportation; and ever-increasing data storage and processing demands. This REU site will advance the current understanding of fundamental heat and mass transfer, while translating discoveries to applied technologies for thermal management at the nano-/microscale, component, and system scales. For 10 weeks during the summer, students will be immersed in research projects tied to emerging technologies, such as metal-air batteries and nanofluidic and micro-/nanostructural thermal transport enhancement, while also learning the role of thermal-fluids engineers in the micro-/power electronics, chemical/material processing, transportation, and energy industries. The site will be interdisciplinary, approaching topics in thermal management from mechanical and chemical engineering perspectives. Activities will include lunches with faculty, research skills seminars, lab/industry tours, preparation for the GRE, and social activities. Participants will have multiple one-on-one advising sessions with the Principle Investigator to define and develop a plan for achieving personal goals, and students' progress will be tracked after the summer ends. The summer will culminate with students preparing a technical report, conference proceeding, or journal article as well as presenting their research results through a poster and oral presentation at a final research symposium. The fall after their summer experience, some of the students will have the choice of presenting their posters at ASME's International Mechanical Engineering Conference and Exposition or AIChe's Student Conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this REU Site: Thermal Management on Multiple Scales are to expand student participation in thermal management research and to attract a diverse pool of curious, motivated students into engineering careers. The program achieved the following technical, professional development, and participation goals.

 

Technical Goals: 

 Students 

(1)   Obtained a solid technical foundation in the thermal sciences through participation in a four-day heat transfer boot camp and by exploring their specific research topics in-depth

(2)   Developed research skills including conduct of ethical research, critical thinking, and review of relevant technical literature

(3)   Learned about the variety of REU topics and related academic research through lunches with faculty members

(4)   Gained exposure to industrial careers in the thermal sciences through tours of The Boeing Company, Maryland Heights Renewable Energy Center, McClure Engineering, Bayer, Hunter Engineering, and Proctor & Gamble.

 

Professional Development Goals: 

 Students 

(1)   Communicated technical research results to a general audience through oral presentations, visual research posters, and written reports or research manuscripts

(2)   Prepared academic/professional goals and a plan to achieve them after the summer ends through one-on-one advising sessions with the PI

(3)   Gained a clear understanding of the preparation needed to apply to and attend graduate school

(4)   Formed a cohort of undergraduate researchers comprising participants in this REU site as well as other Washington University (Wash U) engineering summer undergraduate research programs. This was accomplished via structured (but optional) living arrangements, social events, and group activities.

 

Participants:

Between 2019-2022, this REU site hosted 30 student participants.

  1. 43% were from academic institutions where research opportunities in STEM are limited
  2. 50% were women
  3. 30% were underrepresented minorities (Black or African American, Hispanic or Latino, American Indian or Alaskan Native, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander) or people with disabilities

Of the 21 students who have graduated (the remaining students are still pursuing BS degrees),

  • 62% (n=13) have or are pursuing graduate degrees in engineering
  • 29% (n=6) are pursuing PhDs in engineering
  • 33% (n=7) have or are pursuing MS degrees in engineering

Of the participants who attended institutions with limited STEM research opportunities, which were mostly liberal arts colleges, 64% (n=7) later pursued engineering degrees through dual degree programs.
